Package gameobjects

Class GameObject

  • java.lang.Object
    • gameobjects.GameObject
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    AnimatedGameobject, EgoObject, FallingStar, RectObject, TextObject
    public class GameObject
extends java.lang.Object
    The class GameObject represents an object appearing in a level of the game described by an instance of the class Playground. An instance of GameObject has the following properties:
    • a name that is unique within a certain Playground
    • 2D screen position x and y in pixels
    • 2D speed x and y in pixels/s
    • a reference to the Playground object it belongs to

    In order to allow a flexible composition of object properties, an instance of GameObject is an aggregation of up to three instances of other classes. To put it another way, each instance has attributes that are references to:
    • a subclass of ObjectController that handles the movement/input logic of the object
    • a subclass of Collider that handles the collision detection of the object
    • a subclass of Artist that draws the object
    When a GameObject is constructed using new, all of these references are set to null. In this state, the object does nothing, collides with nothing and is not visible because it is not drawn. You can use calls to the methods setColliders(java.util.LinkedList<collider.Collider>), addArtist(rendering.Artist), addCollider(collider.Collider) and setController(controller.ObjectController) to set these references later, thus giving to an object a behavior, the ability to collide with others, and a visual appearance.
    Normally, it is not necessary to create subclasses of GameObject since the composition of different behavior, collision and appearance properties is governed by subclassing the classes ObjectController, Collider and Artist and then adding them to the GameObject instance.
    However, some subclasses of GameObject define convenience constructors where you can directly provide these references to have more readable code. Examples are: AnimatedGameobject, TextObject, RectObject and EgoObject.

      • GameObject

        public GameObject​(java.lang.String id,
                  Playground playground,
                  ObjectController controller,
                  double x,
                  double y,
                  double vx,
                  double vy)
        convenience constructor.
        Parameters:
        id - Object name, must be unique
        playground - Level this object should be part of
        controller - Can be null if no controller is needed
        x - X position
        y - Y poition
        vx - X speed
        vy - Y speed

      • GameObject

                  Playground playground,
                  double x,
                  double y,
                  double vx,
                  double vy)
        primary constructor. Intializes al aggregated instances to null, need to be set afterwards.
        Parameters:
        id - Object name, must be unique
        playground - Level this object should be part of
        x - X position
        y - Y poition
        vx - X speed
        vy - Y speed

      • getName

        public java.lang.String getName()

      • generateColliders

        public GameObject generateColliders()
        Can be overwritten in subclasses to generate specific colliders automatically. For example, a TextObject knows its own shape so it can generate the necessary rectangular collider automatically.
        Returns:
        The instance of GameObject that is modified (i.e., this)

        sets colliders.
        Parameters:

        Parameters:

      • addCollider

        public GameObject addCollider​(Collider c)
        Add a collider to the existing list of colliders. If it is null, create it and add the collider anyway.
        Parameters:
        c - A subclass of Collider
        Returns:
        this

      • setObjectFlag

        public void setObjectFlag​(java.lang.String flag,
                          java.lang.Object value)
        convenience method, delegated to the containing Playground instance. Flag is prefixed with object name so it does not interfere with same flags in other objects.
        Parameters:
        flag - Flag name
        value - Flag value

      • getObjectFlag

        public java.lang.Object getObjectFlag​(java.lang.String flag)
        convenience method, delegated to the containing Playground instance. Flag is prefixed with object name.
        Parameters:
        flag - Flag name
        Returns:
        flag value, null if flag does not exist

      • getOrCreateObjectFlag

        public java.lang.Object getOrCreateObjectFlag​(java.lang.String flag,
                                              java.lang.Object createValue)
        convenience method, delegated to the containing Playground instance. Flag is prefixed with object name.
        Parameters:
        flag - Flag name
        createValue - If flag does not exist, create it with this value
        Returns:
        The flag's value, is of type Object so it must be cast

      • collisionDetection

        public boolean collisionDetection​(GameObject other)
        Called by the game engine, DO NOT CALL YOURSELF. Is used to detect collision of this with another GameObject instance other. The task is delegated to the list of aggregated colliders. If there is no aggregated collider, no collisions are reported.
        Parameters:
        other - , a GameObject procided by the game engine
        Returns:
        true or false, depending on whether this an other collide, as determined by both their colliders

      • updateObject

        public void updateObject()
        Is called by the game engine once per time step, DO NOT CALL YOURSELF. Gives an object the chance to react to the current game state, change its position and speed a.s.o, react to user inputs, ... All that is done here is to delegate that task to the aggregated subclass of ObjectController. If that ref is null, nothing happens.

      • draw

        public void draw​(java.awt.Graphics2D g)
        Draws the object in its current state. Is called by the game engine, should NOT be called by the user. All it does it to delegate the task to the aggregated subclass of Artist. If this referene is null, nothing happens.
        Parameters:
        g - Graphics2D object that has all the necessary drawing functionalities

      • setComponentProperty

        public void setComponentProperty​(java.lang.String comp,
                                 java.lang.String property,
                                 java.lang.Object value)
        Experimental, use at your own risk. Uses reflection to call a particular setter method in one of the aggregated instances. Assuming that is exists of course. Duh.
        Parameters:
        comp - The aggregated instance to use. For now, only "controller" is supported.
        property - The property to be set. Assumes that an appropriate setter exists.
        value - Value to be set.
